unnormalised: ## IT: Where Did My Weekend Go?
normalised: ## I-T: Where Did My Weekend Go?

unnormalised: So, you wanted to be in IT, eh? Dreamed of coding your way to riches while sipping chai and listening to Bollywood remixes? Let me tell you, the reality is slightly…different. It's less 'Wall Street' and more 'wall of firewalls,' if you catch my drift. Remember that weekend you were planning in Goa? Yeah, that's getting rerouted to a server room in Navi Mumbai.
normalised: So, you wanted to be in I-T, eh? Dreamed of coding your way to riches while sipping chai and listening to Bollywood remixes? Let me tell you, the reality is slightly different. It's less 'Wall Street' and more 'wall of firewalls,' if you catch my drift. Remember that weekend you were planning in Goa? Yeah, that's getting rerouted to a server room in Navi Mumbai.

unnormalised: First of all, forget the romantic notion of a "9 to 5." In IT, that's more like a "9 AM one day to 5 AM the next." Especially when the server decides to throw a tantrum at 23:59 hrs on a Saturday night. And why does it always happen right when the India vs. Pakistan cricket match is about to start? Murphy's Law, probably written by another disgruntled IT guy.
normalised: First of all, forget the romantic notion of a "nine to five." In I-T, that's more like a "nine A-M one day to five A-M the next." Especially when the server decides to throw a tantrum at twenty three fifty nine hours on a Saturday night. And why does it always happen right when the India versus Pakistan cricket match is about to start? Murphy's Law, probably written by another disgruntled I-T guy.

unnormalised: Then there's the jargon. You think you speak English? Think again. You'll be fluent in acronyms you never knew existed. RAM, ROM, CPU, DNS, VPN… it's like alphabet soup gone rogue. You'll be dreaming in binary code, my friend. And don't even get me started on the cloud. It's not fluffy and friendly like the ones in the sky, it's more like a virtual beast that needs constant feeding. Like a demanding mother-in-law, but with data instead of demands for grandchildren.

It's not fluffy and friendly like the ones in the sky, it's more like a virtual beast that needs constant feeding. Like a demanding mother-in-law, but with data instead of demands for grandchildren.

unnormalised: And let's not forget the users. Ah, the users. Bless their hearts. They're convinced the internet is powered by fairy dust and that Ctrl+Alt+Delete is some kind of magical spell. You'll spend hours explaining why turning it off and on again actually *does* work, and why their password "password123" isn't exactly Fort Knox.

You'll spend hours explaining why turning it off and on again actually does work, and why their password "password one two three" isn't exactly Fort Knox.

unnormalised: The constant battle against viruses is another joy. It's like playing whack-a-mole, but with malicious code instead of cute, cartoon rodents. And just when you think you've squashed them all, a new, even more insidious one pops up, probably created by some teenager in Siberia with too much time on his hands.

unnormalised: But hey, it's not all doom and gloom. There's the satisfaction of fixing a problem that nobody else can. The feeling of power when you bring a system back from the brink of disaster. And the camaraderie with your fellow IT soldiers, united in their shared suffering (and caffeine addiction).

And the camaraderie with your fellow I-T soldiers, united in their shared suffering and caffeine addiction.

unnormalised: So, is IT worth it? Maybe. If you're prepared to sacrifice your social life, your sanity, and your weekend getaways to the digital gods. But hey, at least you’ll have a good story to tell… once you've recovered from the burnout. And let's be honest, who else is gonna fix your auntie's email when she accidentally deletes everything? Plus, you might even get free chai from the office canteen, if you play your cards right.
